node.title: Canada expands its list of vaccines accepted for travel.
node.alt: Drivers crossing the United States-Canadian border in Blaine, Wash., in August. Travelers planning a trip of under 72 hours departing from Canada will no longer be required to take a coronavirus test to re-enter the country.
node.description: Officials also removed a test requirement for eligible travelers re-entering Canada within 72 hours.
node.content: ["With the holiday travel season nearing, Canadian officials announced several measures on Friday meant to standardize international travel and make it easier for Canadians taking short trips to re-enter the country.", "Travelers who are fully vaccinated with the shots from Sinopharm, Sinovac and Covaxin will be allowed to enter Canada starting Nov. 30, opening the door wider to people from countries like India, Brazil and China, where those vaccines are more frequently administered.", "Currently, Canada only accepts travelers who have received the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Oxford-AstraZeneca or Johnson & Johnson vaccines, the four shots approved in the country. The expanded list will align with the vaccines cleared for use by the World Health Organization.", "Dr. Theresa Tam, Canada\u2019s chief public health officer, said that the case rates associated with each of the vaccines were about the same. ", "\u201cAll that is very reassuring,\u201d Dr. Tam said. She added that although Sinopharm, Sinovac and Covaxin \u201care not authorized in Canada, because they\u2019ve gone through the W.H.O. process in terms of evaluation of safety, of efficacy and of quality, we\u2019ve taken that into account as we increase the list of vaccines for Canadian border measures.\u201d", "Additionally, people leaving Canada by land or by air for less than 72 hours will no longer be required to provide proof of a negative Covid-19 test to re-enter the country. The price and processing time of P.C.R. tests \u2014 which can cost more than $100 and take longer than a day for results \u2014 were widely seen as deterrents to travel.", "This change applies only to Canadians, permanent residents and Indigenous people registered under the Indian Act. It also takes effect Nov. 30.", "The government will take a firm stance against unvaccinated travelers entering and leaving the country beginning on that date as well, with \u201cvery few exemptions,\u201d said Omar Alghabra, Canada\u2019s transport minister. He added that only fully vaccinated travelers would be able to fly from a Canadian airport or board a Via Rail or Rocky Mountaineer train.", "Starting Jan. 15, Canada will also phase out most previously granted travel exemptions for those who are unvaccinated. This will affect professional and amateur athletes, foreign students, truck drivers and other essential workers who cross the border, and adults over 18 traveling to reunite with a family member.", "Other categories of unvaccinated or partly vaccinated travelers \u2014 such as refugees, marine crews and agricultural workers \u2014 will be able to enter only with limited approval."]
